Graphical abstract Spin and orbital modulation of multi-atomic sites by high-entropy effect was proposed to catalyze cascade sulfur conversion. The high-spin Fe and Mn strongly interact with LiPS through d-p and p-s hybridization, which facilitates the sulfur reduction and evolution reaction. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered a potential candidate for next-generation energy-dense and sustainable energy storage. However, the slow conversion and severe shuttle of polysulfides (LiPSs) result in rapid performance degradation over long-term cycling. Herein, we report a high-entropy single-atom (HE-SA) catalyst to regulate the multi-step conversion of LiPS to attain a high-performance Li-S battery. Both the density functional theory calculations and the experimental results prove that the Fe atomic site with high spin configurations strongly interacts with Li2S4 through d-p and s-p synergistic orbital hybridization which facilitates the reduction of LiPS. Moreover, S-dominant p-d hybridization between Li2S and a high-spin Mn site weakens the Li–S bond and facilitates the rapid sulfur evolution reaction. Consequently, the Li-S battery with a bifunctional HE-SA catalyst shows an ultralow capacity decay of 0.026 % per cycle over 1900 cycles at 1 C. This work proposes a high-entropy strategy for sculpting electronic structures to enable spin and orbital hybridization modulation in advanced catalysts toward long-cycling Li-S batteries. Keywords Electronic spin state Orbital hybridization High-entropy effect Multi-atomic catalysts Sulfur conversion reaction Li-S battery 1 Introduction Currently, traditional lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been difficult to fulfill human needs and social development owing to their low specific energy (350 Wh kg−1) [1–3]. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are regarded as a promising candidate within the field of energy storage systems because of their promising high energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1 [4–7]. Moreover, the cathode material sulfur is earth-abundant, environmentally friendly, and inexpensive. Nevertheless, severe challenges have obstructed the practical application of the sulfur cathode. Typical LSBs fully achieve the high theoretical capacity (1675 mAh g−1) from the conversion of sulfur, wherein slow kinetics and drastic volume variation occur that involve the generation of soluble lithium polysulfide (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8) intermediates, consequently resulting in a continuous loss of the active materials and poor cycling life [8–12]. Utilizing electrocatalysts that can immobilize and expedite the redox reaction of LiPSs is regarded as a root-cause approach to tackle these challenges [13–18]. In particular, the atomic-level electrocatalysts, involving single-atom (SA) and dual-atom (DA), have been explored to improve sulfur utilization and performance because of their extremely high atom utilization efficiency [19–24]. Unfortunately, SA catalysts suffer from the positive correlation between the activity of catalysts and the symmetry reduction, which hinders the aspect of maximizing the adsorption and redox reaction of LiPS. Although DA catalysts break this symmetry to some extent, the scaling relationship limit, which leads to slow sulfur conversion kinetics, has not been fundamentally resolved. In this regard, a chaotic system with high-entropy single atoms (HE-SA) could be the ideal method to solve the above problem. In terms of composition, the high-entropy materials are single-phase solid solutions, which are composed of five or more metallic elements with a concentration of each metallic element being between 5 and 35 atom% [25]. Moreover, high-entropy materials can be defined by a configurational entropy (S config) ≥ 1.5 R (calculated by S config = −R ∑ i = 1 n x i l n x i , where R represents the ideal gas constant, n represents the total number of compositional elements, and xi represents the molar concentration of the ith element) and have attracted substantial attention in the energy-dense batteries based on conversion reactions [26–31]. Particularly, HE-SA has emerged with promising properties because of their compositional diversity on isolated metal (M) atomic sites. Compared with traditional SA and DA catalysts, the existence of the multiple atomic metal sites in HE-SA leads to resilient lattice arrangement at the atomic scale and enables the cooperative regulation of the electronic configuration and d-band engineering, which is referred to as the cocktail effect [32]. In addition, the existence of various active metal sites can regulate the electronic structure, orbital configuration, and catalytic activity through long-range interaction, similar to DA catalysts [33]. More importantly, it has been found that the spin states of the transition metal at the atomic level play a critical role in determining catalytic activity [34]. This enables researchers to tune the catalytic activity of HE-SA by changing the spin-configurations of metal sites leading to promising opportunities to design the desired electrocatalyst toward sulfur conversion reaction, surpassing the performance of SA and DA catalysts. In principle, the atomic magnetic moment in the 3d transition metals is mainly determined through the spin electron orbital filling and its exchange interactions [35]. Meanwhile, the sulfur conversion reaction behavior is intricately connected to the electronic spin configurations and the orbital interactions. For example, Yan et al. found that nitrogen doping in Co-SA catalysts (CoSAC@NC) can induce more electrons to fill higher-energy d-orbitals, thus triggering an alteration of crystal field splitting and a degeneracy-lift in Co d-orbital, which ultimately results in a high-spin state of Co [36]. The improvement of the d-p orbital interactions by the high-spin configuration reduces the energy barrier and improves the kinetics of the sulfur reduction reaction (SRR). Wang's group reported that the strong interaction between the conducive hexagonal cobalt-organic framework (Co-HTP) and the carboxyl graphene (CG) via axial Co–O coordination can modulate the electronic configuration of Co site from low-spin to high-spin state, thus enhancing orbital hybridization with polysulfides and resulting in easier LiPSs adsorption and faster conversion kinetics [37]. Similarly, the degeneracy of the 3d-orbital and the electronic spin state of Fe are switched from the intermediate spin to the low spin by the axial click confinement [38]. Therefore, the d-p orbital interaction between the Fe atoms and the LiPSs is enhanced, leading to improved adsorption energy and catalytic activity in Li-S batteries. In addition to S-dominant p-d orbital hybridization, recently, researchers have also begun to focus on the s-p orbital hybridization between polysulfides and multisite SA catalysts, which also plays a vital role in the catalytic activity [39]. However, the spin regulation of HE-SA catalysts and the synergistic mechanism of d-p and s-p hybridization with LiPS remain unexplored in Li-S batteries. Herein, considering the distinct d-electron configurations of fourth-period transition metals, a HE-SA catalyst with five homogeneously dispersed transition metal centers (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) is synthesized for the cascade catalysis of multi-step polysulfide conversion for the Li-S batteries. Enlightened by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we are excited to find that high-spin Fe and Mn in the HE-SA play dominant roles during the SRR and sulfur evolution reaction (SER) processes, respectively. Specifically, the Fe site dominates the reduction reaction of Li2S4 through the synergistic mechanism of d-p and s-p hybridization, and the Mn site mainly dominates the oxidation reaction of Li2S through d-p hybridization. The realized rapid bidirectional catalysis in the sulfur redox process was confirmed by a series of spectrum and electrochemical characterization technologies. Thus, the Li-S batteries with the HE-SA exhibit a high capacity of 1060 mAh g−1 at 1 C and show excellent cycling stability with an extremely low decay rate of 0.026 % for 1900 cycles. This study illustrates that the spin regulation of HE-SA catalysts and the synergistic effects mechanism of d-p and s-p hybridization with LiPS can efficiently facilitate the redox reactions of Li-S batteries, offering novel perspectives on the rational design of the catalysts with multiple active sites. 2 Results and discussion The microstructure and morphology of the as-obtained HE-SA on the carbon cloth (CC) were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), as exhibited in Fig. 1 (a, b). The catalyst materials in the shape of a rhombododecahedron are stably dispersed on the CC. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) analyses verify the non-crystalline structure of the particles and eliminate the existence of metal clusters or nanoparticles, illustrating a good distribution of Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu atoms, which corresponds to energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) results (Fig. 1c and Fig. S1). A spherical aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) image exhibits the good dispersion of metal single atoms in the carbon substrate (Fig. 1d). To further reveal the coordination environments of HE-SA, the distance between metal-metal dots was 0.65 ± 0.009 nm by statistical analysis based on the AC-HAADF-STEM tests (Fig. S2), indicating the absence of metallic bonding interactions. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of HE-SA exhibits two broad peaks centered at 26° and 44° (Fig. S3), which can be assigned to (002) and (100) lattice planes of amorphous carbon and partial graphitized carbon, respectively. It is notable that no other diffraction peaks are associated with the metallic and the oxidized forms present in this XRD pattern, indicating that the metal atoms are highly distributed and do not aggregate into nanoparticles. To further explore surface chemical environments and the valence state of different elements, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted. The element contents of Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu were quantified by the XPS measurement (Fig. S4). The results show that the atomic ratios of Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu in HE-SA are 25.38 %, 33.16 %, 12.69 %, 14.33 %, and 14.45 % (Table S1), indicating that the high entropy materials were successfully synthesized [25]. The XPS spectrum of Mn 2p is presented in Fig. 1(e). The 2p 3/2 peak can be resolved into two pairs at 641.1 and 643.0 eV, which correspond to the presence of Mn2+ and Mn3+, separately [40]. The peak at 646.2 eV pertains to the satellite feature of Mn2+. The Fe region scan also exhibits two primary peaks in the Fe 2p 3/2 , with binding energies of 709.2 and 711.9 eV, corresponding to the Fe2+ and Fe3+ valence states, respectively (Fig. 1f) [41]. In addition, the Co 2p spectrum shows two peaks located at 781.2 and 795.9 eV and the associated satellite peaks, corresponding to Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 of the Co–N bonds (Fig. 1g) [42]. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum manifests that the binding energy of the Ni in HE-SA is 855.0 eV (Ni 2p 3/2), which is centered between Ni0 and Ni2+, therefore demonstrating the presence of Ni δ + (0 < δ < 2) centers (Fig. 1h) [43]. In Fig. 1(i), the Cu 2p spectrum shows two peaks at 932.7 and 952.5 eV, which is attributed to Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2 of the cation Cu2+ in HE-SA, respectively [44]. No zero-valent metal peaks are detected for all XPS spectra of HE-SA, therefore demonstrating no metallic clusters or particles in the HE-SA. To further understand the benefits of HE-SA compared to low-entropy single-atom (LE-SA) at the atomic level, DFT calculations were conducted by using two rationally simplified structure models (Fig. S5). The pink-colored area in the charge density differences (CDD) profiles indicates charge depletion, while the blue-colored area corresponds to charge accumulation (Fig. 1j and Fig. S6). The CDD calculations of HE-SA and LE-SA exhibit that the strong electron-accepting capacity of the nitrogen (N) atoms triggered the charge transfers from metal (M) atoms and would result in the positive oxidation state of M sites. Evidently, the Mn and Fe atomic sites of HE-SA showed a larger charge transfer than other metal sites (Fig. 1k and Fig. S7), which could trigger charge redistribution, beneficial for polysulfide adsorption and subsequent conversion process. Furthermore, the partial density of states (PDOS) of the Fe d-orbitals in HE-SA and LE-SA both exhibit larger asymmetry as compared to Co d-orbital counterparts. In addition, the electronic states of Mn and Fe d-orbitals in HE-SA also exhibit larger asymmetry compared to other metal atomic sites, originating from the non-uniform distribution of the electronic states between spin up and spin down (Fig. S8). The asymmetry of the d-orbitals for Fe and Mn in HE-SA will induce spontaneous spin polarization that can supply spin electrons, which is advantageous for bonding with LiPS molecules [41]. To further quantify the spin polarization of HE-SA and LE-SA, corresponding spin density and magnetic moments were calculated (Fig. 1l, m, Figs. S9 and S10). The computational results uncover the existence of two obvious electron spin state domains (spin up and spin down) within the HE-SA/LE-SA material. An examination of the Fe spin electron density shows that HE-SA exhibits a much stronger intensity as compared to LE-SA, which is consistent with the results of magnetic moments. Moreover, Mn and Fe in HE-SA possess a larger magnetic moment than other metal atomic sites, demonstrating their superior spin polarization degree. Generally, the large spin magnetic moment of the transition metals promotes the orbital overlap between the LiPS intermediate and the d-orbital of the metal atomic site, which favors the generation of spin channels for electron transfer, thereby promoting the adsorption of the intermediate [45]. According to the DFT calculations analysis, it can be deduced that the spin states of various metal d-orbitals in HE-SA exhibit different electron filling and energy-level arrangements including Mn (dxy 1 dz 2 1 dx 2− y 2 1 dxz 1 dyz 1), Fe (dxy 2 dz 2 1 dxz 1 dyz 1 dx 2− y 2 1), Co (dxy 2 dx 2− y 2 2 dyz 2 dz 2 1 dxz 0), Ni (dxy 2 dx 2− y 2 2 dyz 2 dz 2 1 dxz 1), and Cu (dxy 2 dx 2− y 2 2 dz 2 2 dyz 2 dxz 1) (Fig. 1n). To explore the polysulfide conversion process detected by different atomic sites in HE-SA, we first investigated their d-p orbital hybridization interaction according to the coordination field theory. In general, the interactions between the metal dxy and dx 2− y 2 orbitals and the molecular orbitals of adsorbate are insignificant due to symmetrical conservation [46]. Thus, the bond strength between the metal sites and LiPSs intermediates is primarily attributed to the hybridization of the metal dxz , dz 2, and dyz orbitals with the adsorbed LiPSs p-orbitals, respectively. Specifically, the metal dz 2-orbital can strongly interact with the S 3pz -orbital of LiPSs to generate σ* and σ bonds, while the metal dyz and dxz orbitals can hybridize with the S py and px orbitals to form Π* and Π bonds, respectively. For HE-SA, Mn and Fe sites with high-spin states can generate high bond orders with different LiPSs by the d-p hybridization (Fig. 1o, Figs. S11 and S12). Therefore, the presence of different cations around the active metal atom sites can participate in the regulation of their electronic spin state, orbital hybridization, and electrocatalytic activity via the non-bonding interaction [34]. Moreover, metal-N coordinated atomic catalysts can also immobilize the LiPSs via the chemical interaction of N–Li bonds. It is more reasonable to consider the s-p hybridization between Li 2s orbitals of LiPS and N 2p orbitals of N coordination atoms. The PDOS results demonstrate the p-band center (εp ) of the N atoms coordinated with Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu being −5.74, −4.87, −5.65, −5.80, and −5.73 eV, respectively. Remarkably, the higher εp will result in a decrease in the occupancy states of antibonding sigma orbital (σ*) generated via the s-p hybridization between the Li+ and the N, therefore weakening the electronic repulsion between the Li+ and the N and improving the interaction between the Li+ and the N, as shown in Fig. 1(p). It is considered that the efficient adsorption of Li2S4 intermediates is crucial to simultaneously accelerate the conversion process and suppress the shuttling effect. To investigate the adsorption capacity of HE-SA and LE-SA catalysts to confine Li2S4, Ultraviolet-visible spectrophotometry (UV-vis) spectra and visualized static adsorption experiments were conducted. Obvious color differences were detected between the various vials. In the absence of adsorbents, the Li2S4 solution shows a dark brown color. After overnight adsorption, the solution including HE-SA was colorless and transparent, demonstrating that most Li2S4 has been adsorbed. On the contrary, the solutions containing LE-SA maintain a strong brown appearance, demonstrating poor Li2S4 adsorption effectiveness. The UV-vis adsorption spectra show that the solution with HE-SA exhibits a much lower absorption peak intensity of Li2S4 than LE-SA. In particular, LiPSs peak of the Li2S4 solution at about 600 nm is observed, which is probably attributed to the polysulfide radical S3·− and almost entirely disappears after adsorption by LE-SA and HE-SA (Fig. 2 a), further confirming that HE-SA has stronger adsorption capability for LiPSs [47,48]. To systematically illustrate the potential of HE-SA to improve adsorption capacity and promote sulfur conversion, DFT calculations were performed. The optimized adsorption energy of Li2S4 (Fig. 2b, Figs. S13 and S14) on the surface of the Fe site in HE-SA is higher than that in LE-SA. Charge density difference analysis between catalysts and Li2S4 further reveals the electron interactions during the adsorption process (Fig. 2c, d). The pink area in CDD diagrams indicates charge depletion, while the blue area corresponds to charge accumulation. The metal-sulfur (M–S) and lithium-nitrogen (Li–N) interactions are witnessed in terms of the significant charge transfer in between. The lithiophilic-sulfiphilic dual functions of HE-SA are expected to improve polysulfide capture and conversion kinetics. The HE-SA shows a higher density state close to the Fermi level compared with LE-SA (Fig. S15), indicating that the entropy-stabilized structure improves the electronic conductivity, potentially accelerating charge transfer in the sulfur reaction processes. Furthermore, the DOS calculation exhibits that the d-band centers of metals atomic sites in HE-SA positively shift toward the Fermi level from Cu to Mn (Fig. 2e), resulting in an increasing interaction between Li2S4 and HE-SA because of less occupied anti-bonding states of M–S bonds. Therefore, Fe and Mn sites possess higher binding energies with Li2S4 among the five metal sites in HE-SA (Fig. 2f). However, the difference in the Li2S4 adsorption strength in Fe and Mn sites of HE-SA is ascribed to the different chemical bonding strengths between the coordinated N site of metal and the Li atoms of Li2S4. Furthermore, the atomic N site of Fe presents the highest p-band center energy level among coordinated N sites in five metals, leading to a corresponding decrease in the occupancy states of the Li–N σ* orbital, thus strengthening the chemical interaction between N and Li. The adsorption and catalysis mechanism of the HE-SA towards Li2S4 in Li-S chemistry was systematically investigated by projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (pCOHP) analysis. The interatomic bonding strength can be assessed by analyzing the integral COHP (ICOHP) below the Fermi level, where the positive and negative ICOHP stands for the antibonding and bonding contribution, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2(g) from Mn to Cu, more anti-bonding states of M–S bonds shift down away from the Fermi level and are occupied, indicating that the M–S bonds are weakened. Meanwhile, the ICOHP of M–S bonds yields a less negative value from Mn to Cu, which is closely correlated to the down-shift of d-band centers. In addition, the COHP of Li–N between N sites in HE-SA and Li in Li2S4 is presented in Fig. 2(h). For Fe–N sites, the bonding states of Li–N are predominantly below the Fermi level with more states filled, while antibonding states of Li–N shift obviously toward the Fermi level, resulting in a reduced occupied state. The Fe–N site in HE-SA has the most negative ICOHP value of Li–N bonds among the five coordinated metal-N sites (Fig. 2i), indicating the strongest Li–N interaction and s-p orbital hybridization, which is consistent with the above analysis results of COHP. Considering that the favorable binding site of LiPS is two Li atoms bonding with HE-SA catalysts, the lithium-ion diffusion kinetics of sulfur electrodes with the different catalysts was evaluated by measuring the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves under different sweep rates (Fig. 2j). The D Li+ was calculated based on the classical Randles-Sevcik equation: I P = (2.69 × 105)n 1.5 AD 0.5 Cv 0.5, where I p is peak current, n is the number of electrons transferred in the redox process, A is the effective electrode area, D is the Li+ diffusion coefficient, C is Li+ concentration in the electrode, and ν represents the scanning rate. Fig. 2(k) shows that the slope of the fitting line precisely reflects the Li+ mobility in the sulfur cathode. Compared with the LE-SA-based cell, the HE-SA-based battery exhibits higher D Li+ during the SRR and SER process, which means a faster lithium-ion diffusion rate and significantly accelerated sulfur conversion kinetics. In addition, we assembled the symmetrical battery using the same working electrodes to reveal the unique function of HE-SA in the sulfur conversion kinetics. Fig. 2(l) shows the CV curves of symmetrical cells for HE-SA and LE-SA electrodes at a scan rate of 3 mV s−1. Obviously, the HE-SA electrode has a relatively higher current response than LE-SA, which indicates that HE-SA facilitates the catalytic conversion of LiPSs and promotes sulfur reaction kinetics. The enhanced current responses in the chronoamperometry profiles of the various symmetric cells with Li2S4 indicate the lithiation/delithiation process [49]. The HE-SA cell presents a higher current response value (2.31 mA cm−2) in chronoamperometry profiles than the LE-SA cell counterpart (1.53 mA cm−2), implying the maximum conversion reaction efficiency on the surface of the HE-SA electrode (Fig. 2m). Fig. 3 (a, b) and Figs. S16–S18 show the adsorption energies of Li2S and corresponding optimized adsorption configurations for different metal sites on various atomic catalyst surfaces. Benefitting from the unique high-entropy effect, the HE-SA exhibits higher adsorption energy values than LE-SA and Mn-SA for Li2S. The calculated charge density difference between different catalysts and Li2S further unveils the electron interaction. The pink-filled region in CDD diagrams indicates charge depletion, while the blue-filled region corresponds to charge accumulation. Under the optimal configuration, Mn sites in HE-SA exhibit greater charge transfer than Fe sites in LE-SA, indicating a superior anchoring effect of Li2S, significantly facilitating the conversion process of Li2S (Fig. 3c, d) [50]. Furthermore, we calculated the COHP for the M–S bonds on different metal sites in HE-SA. From Mn to Cu, the antibonding states of the M–S in HE-SA shift down with more states occupied, while bonding states shift up, contributing to less negative ICOHP (Fig. 3e, g). Due to filling more electrons into the antibonding states and the positive shift of bonding states, the M–S bonds from Mn to Cu in HE-SA are weakened. Moreover, the trends of COHP profiles and ICOHP changes after the adsorption of Li2S by HE-SA are similar, suggesting the approximate degree of s-p orbital hybridization on different M–N active sites (Fig. 3f, g). Additionally, when the discharge product of Li2S is adsorbed on different metal sites in HE-SA, the bond length of S1–Li2 on different mental sites in HE-SA is different. The S1–Li2 bond length on the Mn site is the longest among all the metal sites, indicating that the dissolution of Li2S is most favorable on the Mn site in HE-SA (Fig. S19). This indicates that the HE-SA can effectively accelerate the SER kinetics and improve the bifunctional conversion rate of sulfur. The nucleation process of Li2S was explored through deposition experiments. Based on Faraday’s law, the Li2S precipitation capacity of HE-SA is 340.6 mAh g−1, higher than that of LE-SA (301.0 mAh g−1) (Fig. 3h, i), indicating a stronger acceleration of transformation kinetics in the Li2S deposition process. In addition, HE-SA exhibits a shorter response time to the peak current compared to LE-SA. Furthermore, the nucleation and growth behaviors of Li2S in the two samples were further investigated by utilizing the classical nucleation mode (Fig. S20). HE-SA is more like a two-dimensional transient nucleation model (2DI model) compared to LE-SA, suggesting a more rapid generation of Li2S nucleation [51]. Such rapid nucleation under sudden polarization can lead to an obviously optimized distribution, which is conducive to uniform growth and avoids the formation of dead sulfur. To further explore the effect of high-entropy and spin engineering on the SER ability of HE-SA, Li2S dissolution tests are also conducted by utilizing different asymmetric cells. As shown in Fig. 3(j, k), the HE-SA electrode shows a higher dissolution capacity and a shorter conversion time (450.2 mAh g−1, 32 s) in comparison to LE-SA (383.2 mAh g−1, 58 s). This result indicates that HE-SA can effectively accelerate the dissolution kinetics of Li2S and suppress the passivation effect for catalysts, thus promoting the electrochemical performance in Li-S batteries [52]. In addition, when simulating Li2S6 adsorbed on the HE-SA (Fig. S21), the relatively more negative adsorption energy values in the Fe (−1.03 eV) and Ni (−1.01 eV) sites, indicating that these two metal atoms in the HE-SA dominate the Li2S6 adsorption process. To further explore the sulfur conversion capability of HE-SA and LE-SA, we calculated the activation energy(E a) for the SRR and SER according to the following Arrhenius equation j ∝ k = A × e− E a/ RT , where E a represents the activation energy, R represents the gas constant, A represents a pre-exponential factor, and T represents temperature (Fig. 3l and Fig. S22). In both the long-chain and short-chain LiPSs reaction steps, the E a values of HE-SA are 12.0 and 29.4 kJ mol−1, which are lower than those of LE-SA counterparts, indicating rapid SRR kinetics. In the SER stage, the E a values for the conversion from Li2S to S8 are both smaller compared with LE-SA, suggesting that HE-SA significantly accelerates the SER kinetics. Consequently, the application of HE-SA can obviously reduce the energy barrier of bi-directional sulfur conversion reactions. All in all, the non-bonding interaction of HE-SAs synergistically modulates the electronic spin configuration and accelerates cascade sulfur conversion kinetics, therefore achieving highly efficient electrocatalytic activity of HE-SAs in LSBs. The electrochemical performance of the designed sulfur catalysts was tested in Li-S coin cells. As shown in CV profiles in Fig. 4 (a), the Li-S cell with HE-SA catalysts exhibits a higher peak current and a smaller polarization gap compared to its LE-SA counterpart. Moreover, the magnified galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) curves exhibit that the Li-S cell with HE-SA catalysts exhibits a smaller interfacial energy barrier (16.2 mV) compared with that of the LE-SA-based Li-S cell (18.0 mV), indicating the enhanced nucleation and deposition dynamics of Li2S. The improved discharging capacity could be further verified via the lower initial potential (1.72 V) for the HE-SA-based Li-S battery, demonstrating more reductive Li2S in this battery. Moreover, the activation potential barrier of Li2S in the HE-SA-based Li-S battery (2.28 V) is lower than the LE-SA-based battery (2.29 V), demonstrating the superior catalytic ability of HE-SA toward Li2S oxidation (Fig. 4b). In addition, the HE-SA-based Li-S battery displays superior rate performance in comparison to the LE-SA-based battery, realizing specific capacities of 1572, 1290, 1056, 907, 813, and 740 mAh g−1 at current rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 3 C, separately. Specifically, the HE-SA-based cell achieves an impressive discharge capacity of 1572 mAh g−1, corresponding to an outstanding sulfur utilization of 94 % at 0.1 C (1 C = 1675 mAh g−1). This capacity is remarkably higher compared with that of the LE-SA-based (1001 mAh g−1) cases. Upon returning the current rate to 0.1 C, the battery displays a significantly recovered capacity of 1304 mAh g−1, reflecting excellent capacity retention of 83.0 % at 0.1 C (Fig. 4c). The GCD curves of the HE-SA-based Li-S battery exhibit a higher discharge capacity and a smaller polarization voltage than those of the LE-SA-based battery at different current rates (Fig. 4d, e and Fig. S23). This confirms the rapid polysulfide conversion kinetics of the HE-SA-based Li-S battery. To efficiently evaluate the advantages of HE-SA in the sulfur redox process under different current densities, the discharge capacities of the high-voltage plateau (Q 1) and the discharge capacities of the low-voltage plateau (Q 2) were determined (Fig. 4d). Obviously, the HE-SA-based Li-S cell shows higher Q 2/Q 1compared to the cell based on LE-SA, indicating that HE-SA has superior catalytic activity and effectively enhances the conversion kinetics of LiPSs (Fig. S24). Moreover, this study possesses a significant advance in terms of rate capability compared with those of the previously reported SA catalysts (Fig. 4f and Table S2) [40,53–61]. The rate-capability curve further illustrates that the HE-SA-based catalyst has outstanding catalytic performance, enabling an enhancement of the discharge capacity. Fig. 4(g) exhibits the long-term cyclic performance of various cells at a current density of 0.2 C. The HE-SA-based Li-S cell has a remarkable initial specific capacity of 1373 mAh g−1 and maintains at 914 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles, which is significantly higher than that of the LE-SA-based cell (433 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles). To further prove the superiority of HE-SA, even at a high current density of 1 C, the HE-SA-based battery still achieves a commendable discharge capacity of 1060 mAh g−1 upon activation in the subsequent cycles. Interestingly, the HE-SA cell undergoes a reactivation process and a rapidly increasing discharge capacity during the first few cycles. As the reaction proceeded, sulfur species were rearranged and redistributed uniformly, and the deeper buried sulfur species could be fully utilized [62]. After 1900 cycles, the cell with HE-SA catalysts still possesses a reversible capacity of 533 mAh g−1, with an ultralow capacity decay rate of 0.026 % per cycle (Fig. 4h). In addition, the capacity decay rate of the HE-SA sulfur electrode at 1 C is comparable to, or even exceeds, that of numerous advanced benchmark materials (Fig. 4i and Table S2) [20,42,63–66]. These results suggest that the Li-S cell with HE-SA-based catalysts exhibits high sulfur utilization and outstanding cyclic stability owing to maximized activity by the cocktail effect of multiple metal-N sites. In addition, we verify that HE-SA maintains electrochemically inert cell cycling in the Li-S voltage window (Fig. S25). Therefore, the HE-SA catalyst with similar atomic ratios has a higher configurational entropy, which is beneficial for achieving superior catalytic activity and stability for fast and durable LiPS conversion. Developing energy-dense Li-S batteries requires an electrode with high mass loading and low electrolyte/sulfur ratio (E/S). As depicted in Fig. 4(j), the HE-SA-based Li-S cell with a sulfur loading of 4.1 mg cm−2 and E/S ratio of 12.4 μL mg−1 shows an initial discharge capacity of 1130.6 mAh g−1 after activation in the first cycle. After 140 cycles, the high discharge capacity maintains stable at 773.0 mAh g−1 with only a 0.22 % decay rate per cycle. Furthermore, the corresponding GCD profiles manifest obviously defined plateaus, which coincide with the superior catalytic performance of HE-SA (Fig. 4k). Furthermore, the HE-SA-based electrode exhibits a reversible areal capacity of 4.2 mAh cm−2 when increasing the sulfur loading to 5.0 mg cm−2 and E/S ratio of 9.0 μL mg−1 (Fig. 4l). The two clear discharge plateaus are still maintained during diverse cycles (Fig. 4m). Even further decreasing the E/S ratio to 5.0 μL mg−1, a two-plateau voltage profile is still achievable, with an areal capacity of 5.2 mAh cm−2 (Fig. S26). Charging and discharging in LSBs is intricate electrochemical redox behaviors (Fig. 5 a). Because of the constraints of CV in evaluating battery kinetics, we examined this behavior in detail under real operation conditions by the in-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and the distribution of relaxation times (DRT) analysis. Initially, the dynamic variations of the intrinsic system resistance (R S), the electrolyte/electrode interfacial resistance (R SEI), and the charge transfer resistance (R ct) were also monitored during discharge and charge (Fig. 5b, c and Fig. S27). The HE-SA cell consistently keeps lower R S, R SEI, and R ct than LE-SA, confirming that the former possesses the superior capability of promoting sulfur conversion kinetics. In order to further identify and correlate the principal time constants in impedance measurement to specific electrochemical processes, the impedance spectra were subsequently analyzed by a semi-quantitative DRT approach. As reported by Miller’s group [67], the charging-discharging process of the Li-S battery can be classified into the following eight regions according to DRT analysis, each representing a polarization resistance. Specifically, peaks P1–P3 involve the inter-particle resistance (P1), the double-layer relaxation (P2), and the solid-electrolyte interphase (P3). Peaks P4–P6 are attributed to the conversion of LiPSs at the cathode interface, suggesting the multi-electron charge transfer behavior. Peaks P7 and P8 are associated with Warburg impedance originating from diffusion processes, containing polysulfide diffusion (P7) and bulk ion diffusion (P8), respectively. During the discharge and charge processes, the DRT counter plots of the cells using either HE-SA or LE-SA catalysts show multiple peaks, suggesting specific electrochemical processes across different interfaces. As depicted in Fig. 5(d, e), during the discharge and charge processes, the intensity of the P8 peak first decreases and then increases, demonstrating that the sulfur species undergo solid-liquid-solid transformation reactions. In addition, the P1 peak is almost independent of the various discharge and charge states, which can be ascribed to the total Ohmic resistance (Fig. 5f and Fig. S28a). During the discharge and charge processes, the P2 and P3 combine into a broad peak. The peak intensity firstly increases and then decreases, suggesting that the Li+ resistance at the lithium metal anode progressively increases during the initial solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) generation and begins to diminish as the SEI is stabilized. The P4–P6 peaks in the HE-SA cells exhibit lower intensities than that in the LE-SA cell (Fig. 5g and Fig. S28b), suggesting that HE-SA can effectively accelerate charge transfer and reduce polarization and indicating more rapid kinetics of Li-S conversion. In order to further investigate the conversion process of short-chain LiPS, the fitting DRT curves at discharge to 2.0 and 1.7 V and charge to 2.3 V are shown in Fig. 5(h–j). During the discharge at 2.0 V, the DRT curves of Li-S cells with different catalysts both show P8-dominated peaks. The HE-SA catalyst has a lower peak intensity than the LE-SA catalyst, indicating that the HE-SA catalyst may enhance the complete reduction of the LiPSs into Li2S2 and Li2S. The high-intensity peak in the LE-SA catalyst suggests the incomplete reduction of the short-chain LiPSs, leading to poor S utilization and capacity (Fig. 5h). At a fully discharged state of 1.7 V, the HE-SA catalyst has a higher P8 peak and a lower P6 peak than the LE-SA catalyst, indicating more effective Li2S precipitation induced by virtue of fast charge transfer ability in HE-SA (Fig. 5i) [68]. During the charging process at 2.3 V, the HE-SA and LE-SA catalysts exhibit similar relaxation processes including dominated P6, P7, and P8 peaks. In comparison with the LE-SA catalyst, the HE-SA catalyst exhibits smaller intensity peaks, which can be ascribed to the enhanced conversion rate of polysulfides and improved dissolution efficiency of solid discharge products (Fig. 5j). 3 Conclusions In summary, to address the sluggish kinetics of the SRR and SER processes, we construct multi-active HE-SA catalysts. DFT calculations demonstrate that the high-spin regulation of Fe and Mn active sites in HE-SA as well as the combination of d-p and s-p orbital hybridization with polysulfides can synergistically improve the kinetics of the sulfur redox reaction, leading to an efficient and bidirectional catalytic activity of HE-SA. The HE-SA achieves efficient bidirectional conversion kinetics of sulfur, which is further confirmed by a series of catalysis measurements as well as in-situ EIS and corresponding DRT technologies. Consequently, the Li-S batteries with the HE-SA catalyst illustrate high-rate capability (740 mAh g−1 at 3 C), outstanding cycling stability (0.026 %), and high areal capacity (4.2 mAh cm−2). This study provides a deeper understanding of the synergistic mechanisms of the spin regulation and orbital hybridization of HE-SA with LiPS, enabling the rational design of HE-SA toward boosted Li-S electrocatalysis and beyond. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered a potential candidate for next-generation energy-dense and sustainable energy storage. However, the slow conversion and severe shuttle of polysulfides (LiPSs) result in rapid performance degradation over long-term cycling. Herein, we report a high-entropy single-atom (HE-SA) catalyst to regulate the multi-step conversion of LiPS to attain a high-performance Li-S battery. Both the density functional theory calculations and the experimental results prove that the Fe atomic site with high spin configurations strongly interacts with Li2S4 through d-p and s-p synergistic orbital hybridization which facilitates the reduction of LiPS. Moreover, S-dominant p-d hybridization between Li2S and a high-spin Mn site weakens the Li–S bond and facilitates the rapid sulfur evolution reaction. Consequently, the Li-S battery with a bifunctional HE-SA catalyst shows an ultralow capacity decay of 0.026 % per cycle over 1900 cycles at 1 C. This work proposes a high-entropy strategy for sculpting electronic structures to enable spin and orbital hybridization modulation in advanced catalysts toward long-cycling Li-S batteries.
